dc:description: *PKD1* was first reported in relation to biallelic polycystic kidney disease (PKD) in 2009 (Rossetti et al., PMID: 19165178). *PKD1* has been previously classified as definitive for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Biallelic disease of two fully pathogenic *PKD1* variants results in embryonic lethality and so viable biallelic cases must have at least one hypomorphic allele. This biallelic disease is a significant cause of very early onset PKD and can arise in a family with otherwise typical ADPKD (monoallelic family members). Individuals with a negative family history can have two hypomorphic alleles. At least seventeen unique variants (missense, nonsense, frameshift) that have been reported in thirteen probands in four publications (PMIDs: 19165178, 23624871, 30631912, 33168999) are included in this curation. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached (PMIDs: 26139440, 20558538). This gene-disease relationship is also supported by two mouse models, biochemical function data, and expression data (PMIDs: 9326937, 23064367, 11106764, 31427367, 8981910, 11891195). In summary, *PKD1* is definitively associated with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD-*PKD1*). This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Kidney Cystic and Ciliopathy GCEP on the meeting date 1/11/2023 (SOP Version 9).

evidence.dc:description: Heterozygotes had no discernible phenotype, while homozygotes died during the perinatal period with massively enlarged cystic kidneys, pancreatic ductal cysts, and pulmonary hypoplasia. Renal cyst formation began at embryonic day 15.5 in proximal tubules and progressed rapidly to replace the entire renal parenchyma. No hepatic cysts were observed in the homozygous mutants
evidence.rdfs:label: Knock-out mouse model

evidence.dc:description: Upgraded because the model replicated a human disease causing variant and recapitulated the human phenotype

Pkd1+/null mice were normal. Mirroring the human studies with early-onset severe ADPKD, Pkd1 RC/RC animals developed gradual cystic disease over 1 year, while Pkd1 RC/null mice had rapidly progressive disease, proving the significance of this combination of alleles.Histology of homozygous Pkd1 animals show cysts developing with age, an increased level of fibrosis, ductal plate malformations, including microhamartomas of varying severity. These cystic lesions are progenitors of the liver cysts often found in patients with ADPKD
evidence.rdfs:label: Knock-in mouse model

evidence.dc:description: A fetus or baby with ARPKD has fluid-filled kidney cysts that may make the kidneys too big, or enlarged, causing a child to have poor kidney function, even in the womb.
evidence.rdfs:label: Tubulogenesis

evidence.dc:description:
The authors studied genetic interaction between PKHD1 and PKD1 in digenic mouse and rat models.
Genetic interaction was synergistic in both species, with digenic animals exhibiting phenotypes of rapidly progressive PKD and early lethality resembling ARPKD. Genetic interaction in both murine models reveal distinct thresholds for both Pkhd1 and Pkd1: haploinsufficiency for Pkhd1 or a single Pkd1RC allele do not exacerbate the phenotype, but homozygosity of either allele in the digenic context results in severe disease which highlights the dosage-dependence of PKD
evidence.rdfs:label: Synergistic interaction with PKHD1

evidence.dc:description: Immunohistological studies localized polycystin to renal tubular epithelia, hepatic bile ductules, and pancreatic ducts, all sites of cystic changes in ADPKD, as well as in tissues such as skin that are not known to be affected in ADPKD. Electron microscopy: polycystin was predominantly associated with plasma membranes, and significantly less abundant in adult than in fetal epithelia. In contrast, polycystin was overexpressed in most, but not all, cysts in ADPKD kidneys
evidence.rdfs:label: PKD1 Expression

evidence.dc:description: Expression pattern of PKD1 transcripts and proteins during human embryogenesis and kidney development was studied using Northern blot analysis, in situ hybridization, and immunohistochemical methods. Northern blot analysis in fetal tissues revealed that PKD1 mRNAs were mainly expressed in brain and kidney. In human 5- to 6-week-old embryos, PKD1 is widely expressed, mainly in neural tissue, cardiomyocytes, endodermal derivatives, and mesonephros. Thereafter, high PKD1 expression first appears in differentiated proximal tubules. Proximal tubule expression of PKD1 decreases from weeks 20 to 24 onwards. PKD1 transcripts, later restricted to distal tubules in fetal nephrogenesis, are no longer detected in adult kidneys, which nevertheless maintain a faint expression of polycystin-1.
evidence.rdfs:label: PKD1 expression in human fetal tissues
Case 21
evidence.detectionMethod: LR-PCR & Sanger sequencing of PKD1, PKD2, PKHD1, HNF1B
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Polycystic kidneys detected prenatally; postnatal poor renal function; Renal transplant aged 7

evidence.rdfs:label: Proband II-1
evidence.detectionMethod: Direct sequencing of exonic and flanking intronic regions of PKD1, PKD2, and PKHD1. Linkage analysis with intragenic and flanking markers showed the disease was not due to PKHD1, and partial sequencing of PKHD1 did not identify any likely mutations

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 19
evidence.detectionMethod: Molecular testing of PKD1, PKD2, HNF1B, and PKHD1 genes was performed by direct sequencing, followed by quantitative fluorescent multiplex PCR, Multiplex Ligation-Dependent Probe Amplification (MRC-Holland), and array-comparative genomic hybridization
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: serum creatinine level at 12 months: 25 μM

member.rdfs:label: Proband 1 (II5)
member.detectionMethod: Direct sequencing of exonic and flanking introgenic regions of PKD1 and PKD2.

evidence.dc:description: Haplotype analysis with five markers flanking PKD1 found the N3188S variant to be homozygous in the affected cases and heterozygous in the others
evidence.rdfs:label: Family P192

member.rdfs:label: Proband 3(II2)
member.detectionMethod: Direct sequencing of PKD1, PKD2, PKHD1 exons and flanking regions

evidence.rdfs:label: Family SE44

member.rdfs:label: Proband III-1
member.detectionMethod: Direct sequencing of exonic and flanking intronic regions of PKD1, PKD2, and PKHD1. Linkage analysis with intragenic and flanking markers was performed.
member.phenotypeFreeText: No liver cysts or anomalies detected, Renal transplant after ESRD at 8.5 yrs

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: No liver cysts or anomalies detected

evidence.rdfs:label: Family M34

member.rdfs:label: Proband 2 (II2)
member.detectionMethod: direct sequencing of PKD1, PKHD1 and PKD2 exons and flanking regions
member.phenotypeFreeText: Bilaterally enlarged kidneys and ESRD at age 75 yrs,  multiple, relatively uniformly sized cysts found in kidney which is atypical for ADPKD, and unusually for older ADPKD patients, liver cysts were not found
